S T A T E   O F   N E W   Y O R K
       ________________________________________________________________________

                                         2024

                              2011-2012 Regular Sessions

                                   I N  S E N A T E

                                   January 14, 2011
                                      ___________

       Introduced  by  Sens.  SQUADRON, DIAZ, HASSELL-THOMPSON, KRUEGER -- read
         twice and ordered printed, and when printed to  be  committed  to  the
         Committee on Health

       AN ACT to amend the public health law, in relation to directing that all
         ambulances shall be equipped with epinephrine auto-injector devices

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. The section heading of 3000-c of the public health law,  as
    2  added by chapter 578 of the laws of 1999, is amended to read as follows:
    3    Epinephrine auto-injector devices; COLLABORATIVE AGREEMENT.
    4    S  2. Section 3000-d of the public health law is renumbered 3000-e and
    5  a new section 3000-d is added to read as follows:
    6    S 3000-D. EPINEPHRINE AUTO-INJECTOR DEVICES; AMBULANCE SERVICES.    1.
    7  AS  USED  IN THIS SECTION, "AMBULANCE" SHALL MEAN ANY MOTOR VEHICLE USED
    8  TO PROVIDE EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE AS SUCH TERM IS DEFINED IN  SECTION
    9  THREE THOUSAND ONE OF THIS ARTICLE, WHETHER OWNED BY THE STATE, A MUNIC-
   10  IPAL CORPORATION OR BY A PRIVATE ENTITY.
   11    2.  NOTWITHSTANDING  ANY OTHER PROVISION OF LAW TO THE CONTRARY, EVERY
   12  AMBULANCE SHALL BE EQUIPPED WITH AN EPINEPHRINE AUTO-INJECTOR.
   13    3. ALL EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE  PROVIDERS  SHALL  HAVE  SUCCESSFULLY
   14  COMPLETED  A  TRAINING  COURSE  IN  THE USE OF EPINEPHRINE AUTO-INJECTOR
   15  DEVICES APPROVED BY THE COMMISSIONER.
   16    4. EVERY AMBULANCE SERVICE AUTHORIZED TO POSSESS AND  USE  EPINEPHRINE
   17  AUTO-INJECTOR  DEVICES  PURSUANT TO THIS SECTION SHALL USE, MAINTAIN AND
   18  DISPOSE OF SUCH DEVICES PURSUANT TO REGULATIONS OF THE DEPARTMENT.
   19    5. USE OF AN EPINEPHRINE AUTO-INJECTOR DEVICE PURSUANT TO THIS SECTION
   20  SHALL BE CONSIDERED EMERGENCY TREATMENT FOR THE PURPOSE OF  ANY  STATUTE
   21  RELATING TO LIABILITY.
   22    S 3. This act shall take effect on the one hundred eightieth day after
   23  it shall have become a law.

        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2024

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the public health law, in relation to directing that all
ambulances shall be equipped with epinephrine auto-injector devices

PURPOSE OR GENERAL IDEA OF BILL:
This bill directs that all ambulances
shall be equipped with epinephrine auto-injector devices.

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
Section one amends section heading
3000-c of the public health law to read: Epinephrine auto-injector
devices; collaborative agreement.

Section two adds section 3000-d to the public health law. This section
defines the term "ambulance" and requires that each one shall be
equipped with an epinephrine auto-injector. It stipulates that all
emergency medical services providers shall successfully complete a
training Course in the use of epinephrine auto-injector devices. It
also stipulates that every ambulance shall use, maintain and dispose
of these devices according to the department's regulations and that
use of such devices shall be considered emergency treatment under
liability statutes.

Section three sets out the effective date.

JUSTIFICATION:
Epinephrine auto-injectors are used to
treat
anaphylactic shock. They are commonly prescribed to and carried by
persons with severe allergies because they can be self-administered
and are fast-acting. Current New York State ambulatory regulations do
not require basic life support ambulances to carry epinephrine
auto-injectors. Only Advanced Life Support ambulances carry the
devices and they commonly respond to only more life-threatening
emergencies. This regulation would ensure that any ambulance
responding to an emergency would be equipped to treat people
suffering from anaphylactic shock.

PRIOR LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
2010: S.5291/A.6416-A

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
Undetermined.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the one hundred and eightieth day after
becoming a law.
